constructs.name: perceived_engineering_competence
constructs.description: Subjective sense of being a capable, skilled engineer - the core feeling of 'I am good at this and belong here'

constructs.name: self_efficacy
constructs.description: Confidence in one's ability to successfully complete engineering tasks and solve complex technical problems

constructs.name: imposter_syndrome
constructs.description: Feeling like a fraud, that successes are due to luck, and persistent anxiety about being 'found out' as incompetent

constructs.name: task_performance
constructs.description: Perceived success in completing engineering work - code working, bugs fixed, problems solved, features shipped

constructs.name: external_validation
constructs.description: Recognition, positive feedback, and acknowledgment from peers, managers, code reviews, or users

constructs.name: technical_skill_growth
constructs.description: Sense of learning new skills, understanding new concepts, and expanding engineering knowledge over time

constructs.name: learning_engagement
constructs.description: Active engagement in learning activities - reading documentation, studying codebases, experimenting with new technologies

constructs.name: deliberate_practice
constructs.description: Intentional effort to improve skills through challenging work, feedback seeking, and reflection on mistakes

constructs.name: cognitive_clarity
constructs.description: Mental sharpness, ability to focus deeply, and capacity to think clearly about complex technical problems

constructs.name: emotional_wellbeing
constructs.description: Overall mood and emotional state - positive affect, energy, absence of anxiety or depressive symptoms

constructs.name: sleep_quality
constructs.description: Quality and restorativeness of sleep - feeling rested and recovered

constructs.name: work_stress
constructs.description: Level of work-related stress, pressure, overwhelm, and demanding conditions

constructs.name: social_comparison
constructs.description: Tendency to compare oneself to peer engineers, often unfavorably to high performers

constructs.name: task_challenge_level
constructs.description: Difficulty and complexity of current engineering tasks relative to current ability level

constructs.name: psychological_safety
constructs.description: Feeling safe to take risks, ask questions, admit mistakes without fear of judgment or punishment

constructs.name: peer_support
constructs.description: Quality of support, help, collaboration, and positive interaction with engineering colleagues

constructs.name: professional_identity
constructs.description: Strength of identification with being an engineer as core to one's professional sense of self

constructs.name: autonomy
constructs.description: Sense of control and independence in how one approaches and completes engineering work

constructs.name: growth_orientation
constructs.description: Trait-level belief that abilities can be developed through effort and learning (growth mindset)

constructs.name: perfectionism
constructs.description: Trait-level tendency toward unrealistically high standards and harsh self-criticism when falling short

constructs.name: neuroticism
constructs.description: Trait-level tendency toward negative affect, anxiety, and self-doubt

constructs.name: years_of_experience
constructs.description: Total years of professional engineering experience

constructs.name: underrepresented_identity
constructs.description: Whether the person holds an underrepresented identity in engineering contexts (gender, race, etc.)

edges.description: Higher confidence in ability directly feeds subjective sense of competence
Imposter feelings directly undermine sense of being a competent engineer
Successfully completing engineering tasks provides direct evidence of competence
Recognition from others provides social proof of one's engineering competence
Sensing skill development over time builds perception of growing competence
Strong identification as engineer supports beliefs about one's engineering competence
Unfavorable comparisons with high-performing peers undermine competence perception
Having autonomy signals trust in one's competence and enables demonstrating capability
Mastery experiences are the strongest source of self-efficacy (Bandura)
Positive feedback from others builds confidence in one's abilities
Positive emotional state supports confident self-appraisal of capabilities
Learning new skills builds confidence in ability to handle challenges
Growth mindset supports resilient self-efficacy beliefs despite setbacks
Imposter feelings erode confidence in one's engineering abilities
Perfectionist standards make normal performance feel inadequate, fueling fraud feelings
Trait anxiety and self-doubt predispose to imposter experiences
Unfavorable comparisons with peers trigger feelings of being a fraud
Underrepresentation in engineering heightens feelings of not belonging
Low psychological safety amplifies fear of being exposed as incompetent
Higher self-efficacy provides buffer against imposter feelings
Mental sharpness enables better problem-solving and task execution
Greater accumulated skills enable better task performance
Confidence enables persistence and effective problem-solving approach
Task difficulty relative to ability affects likelihood of successful completion
Getting help and collaboration from peers improves task outcomes
High stress impairs cognitive performance on complex engineering tasks
Having control over approach enables more effective problem-solving
Good work performance leads to positive recognition from others
Psychologically safe environments encourage giving and receiving feedback
Supportive peers more readily provide acknowledgment and recognition
Active learning engagement leads to skill development
Intentional effortful practice builds engineering expertise
Appropriately challenging work stretches abilities and promotes growth
More experience provides foundation for faster skill acquisition
Feedback helps identify areas for improvement and confirms progress
Growth mindset motivates active engagement in learning
Feeling safe enables exploration and learning from mistakes
Mental energy and clarity enables engaging with new learning material
Confidence supports taking on challenging learning activities
Engagement with learning drives intentional practice efforts
Confidence motivates seeking out challenging practice opportunities
Positive feedback motivates continued effort to improve skills
Belief in growth through effort motivates deliberate practice
Good sleep is essential for cognitive function and mental sharpness
High stress impairs focus and clear thinking on complex problems
Positive mood supports clearer, more flexible thinking
Poor sleep impairs emotional regulation and lowers mood
Work stress depletes emotional resources and lowers wellbeing
Social support from colleagues improves emotional state
Trait neuroticism predisposes to lower baseline emotional wellbeing
Success at work improves mood and emotional state
Feeling competent at one's craft supports positive emotional state
Work stress disrupts sleep through rumination and physiological arousal
Poor mood and anxiety impair sleep quality
Excessively challenging tasks create stress and pressure
Low safety creates chronic stress about judgment and failure
Poor sleep reduces resilience to workplace stressors
Lack of control increases work stress (demand-control model)
Imposter anxiety creates chronic background stress and vigilance
Imposter feelings drive comparison-seeking to assess where one stands
Peer interactions provide opportunities for social comparison
Perfectionism drives comparison with highest achievers
Supportive collaborative peers create safer team environment
Receiving positive validation builds sense of safety to take risks
Safe environments encourage seeking and offering collegial support
Positive mood facilitates seeking and receiving support from peers
More experienced engineers are assigned more complex challenging work
Strong performance leads to being assigned more challenging tasks
Successful engineering work strengthens identity as engineer
Growing skills reinforce engineering professional identity
More experience solidifies professional identity as engineer
Being recognized as capable engineer reinforces professional identity
Safe environments enable being granted and exercising autonomy
Confidence leads to seeking and being granted more autonomy
More experienced engineers typically receive greater autonomy

indicators.name: technical_documentation_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to technical documentation sites: hackage.haskell.org, wiki.haskell.org, MDN, readthedocs, docs.python.org, archlinux wiki, official API references. Include any URL containing '/docs/', '/documentation/', '/api/', '/reference/', or '/manual/'.

indicators.name: tutorial_and_learning_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to learning resources: learnxinyminutes.com, sites with 'tutorial' in URL or title, searches containing 'tutorial', 'learn', 'getting started', 'introduction to', 'beginner guide', 'how to start with'. Include Coursera, Udemy, edX for technical content.

indicators.name: advanced_concept_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches or visits involving advanced programming concepts: monads, functors, applicatives, type theory, category theory, dependent types, higher-kinded types, lambda calculus, referential transparency, cryptographic protocols (TLS, AES, PUF), consensus algorithms.

indicators.name: distinct_technical_domains
indicators.how_to_measure: Count distinct technical domains present in browsing. Count each once if any related search/visit exists: functional programming=1, cryptography/security=1, systems/Linux=1, databases=1, web development=1, blockchain=1, hardware=1, networking=1, mobile=1, ML/AI=1.

indicators.name: coding_challenge_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to coding practice sites: leetcode.com, hackerrank.com, codewars.com, exercism.io, projecteuler.net, topcoder.com, adventofcode.com, codeforces.com. Include searches containing 'coding challenge', 'algorithm practice', 'programming exercise'.

indicators.name: best_practices_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches about improvement and quality: 'best practice', 'best way to', 'idiomatic', 'clean code', 'design pattern', 'refactoring', 'code review tips', 'common mistakes', 'anti-pattern', 'code smell'.

indicators.name: error_debugging_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches indicating debugging: error messages in quotes, 'not working', 'doesn't work', 'won't compile', 'bug', 'broken', 'failed', 'exception', 'crash', 'undefined'. Include Stack Overflow visits where title contains error-related terms.

indicators.name: implementation_how_to_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count implementation-focused searches: 'how to implement', 'how do I', 'example of', specific function lookups (e.g., 'foldr haskell', 'map reduce'), API usage queries, 'sample code'. Indicates active building work.

indicators.name: professional_platform_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to professional recognition platforms: linkedin.com, github.com profile/notification pages, news.ycombinator.com/user or /submitted pages, twitter.com or x.com. Focus on pages where one checks engagement, likes, stars, or responses.

indicators.name: code_review_page_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to code review pages: URLs containing '/pull/', '/pulls', '/merge_requests/', 'review', GitHub PR pages, GitLab MR pages, Gerrit, Phabricator. These are where feedback is given/received.

indicators.name: unrelated_topic_switches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count transitions between unrelated topics in sequence. Each jump counts as 1: programming→shopping=1, security→recipes=1, haskell→travel=1. Related consecutive items count as 0 switches: haskell monad→haskell functor=0, thinkpad x1→thinkpad t14=0.

indicators.name: focused_technical_session
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if there are 5 or more consecutive technical searches/visits on related topics without interruption by unrelated content (e.g., 5+ Haskell items in a row, or 5+ security items in a row), 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: late_night_activity_present
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if any browsing entry has timestamp between 00:00 and 05:00 (midnight to 5 AM), 0 otherwise. Check the hour component of each timestamp.

indicators.name: first_activity_hour
indicators.how_to_measure: Record the hour (0-23) from the earliest timestamp in the data. Example: if first entry is 10:32, record 10. If first entry is 07:15, record 7. If first entry is 00:45, record 0.

indicators.name: sleep_fatigue_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches about sleep or tiredness: 'sleep', 'insomnia', 'tired', 'fatigue', 'exhausted', 'melatonin', 'can't sleep', 'sleep schedule', 'sleep quality', 'nap', 'restless', 'circadian'. Include sleep tracker app/device searches.

indicators.name: stress_burnout_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches about stress or burnout: 'stress', 'stressed', 'burnout', 'burned out', 'overwhelmed', 'work anxiety', 'work-life balance', 'need a break', 'too much work', 'overworked', 'mental health day'.

indicators.name: work_hours_distraction_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to entertainment sites with timestamps between 09:00-18:00: reddit.com (non-programming subs), youtube.com (non-technical), social media, shopping sites, news/media sites, games. Exclude technical subreddits and educational videos.

indicators.name: mental_health_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches about mental/emotional health: 'depression', 'depressed', 'anxiety', 'anxious', 'therapy', 'therapist', 'counseling', 'mental health', 'feeling down', 'lonely', 'psychiatrist', 'antidepressant', 'ketamine therapy', 'psilocybin'.

indicators.name: positive_recreation_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to recreational/lifestyle content: travel sites (booking, tripadvisor, airline sites), music (spotify, bandcamp, concerts), restaurants/food, hobbies, events, entertainment. Indicates engagement with positive life activities.

indicators.name: other_developer_profile_views
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to other people's professional profiles: LinkedIn profiles (URLs with '/in/'), GitHub user pages (github.com/username without /repo), personal portfolio sites, tech blogger about pages. Exclude repository pages and own profiles.

indicators.name: salary_career_comparison_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches comparing compensation or status: 'engineer salary', 'developer salary', 'levels.fyi', 'glassdoor', 'compensation', 'how much do engineers make', 'senior engineer salary', 'FAANG salary', 'total comp'.

indicators.name: imposter_syndrome_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches about imposter feelings: 'imposter syndrome', 'feel like a fraud', 'not good enough', 'don't belong', 'everyone is smarter', 'fake it till you make it', 'not a real engineer', 'out of my depth'.

indicators.name: qualification_checking_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches checking qualifications anxiously: 'what should engineers know', 'skills needed for senior', 'do I need CS degree', 'am I qualified', 'job requirements' (when not actively job hunting), 'engineering interview' (anxious prep).

indicators.name: ambitious_project_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches about tackling ambitious work: 'build my own', 'from scratch', 'implement X myself', system design topics, architecture decisions, starting new projects, taking on complex features. Shows confidence to attempt difficult things.

indicators.name: basic_concept_lookups
indicators.how_to_measure: Count very elementary lookups: 'what is a variable', 'what is a function', 'what is an API', basic syntax for known languages, 'for loop tutorial', elementary definitions. Very basic questions for experienced topics suggest lower confidence.

indicators.name: proactive_technical_research
indicators.how_to_measure: Count exploratory technical searches not tied to immediate problems: browsing library documentation without errors, reading technical blogs, exploring language features, investigating new frameworks, reading open source code. Curiosity-driven rather than problem-driven.

indicators.name: competence_self_assessment_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches evaluating own ability: 'am I a good developer', 'how to know if good engineer', 'engineering skill assessment', 'what level engineer am I', 'self-taught developer good enough', 'rate my skills'.

indicators.name: technical_qa_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to technical Q&A sites: stackoverflow.com, stackexchange sites (unix, security, dba), reddit programming help threads (/r/learnprogramming, /r/AskProgramming). Higher counts suggest more challenging work requiring help.

indicators.name: academic_technical_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to academic/research sources: arxiv.org, scholar.google.com, sci-hub, researchgate.net, acm.org, ieee.org, university .edu pages with technical content, academic papers. Indicates engagement with cutting-edge complexity.

indicators.name: workplace_safety_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches about workplace safety concerns: 'afraid to ask questions', 'fear of asking', 'toxic workplace', 'psychological safety', 'hostile work', 'fear of judgment', 'HR complaint', 'speak up at work', 'retaliation'.

indicators.name: public_question_posting
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if visit to question submission pages exists (stackoverflow.com/questions/ask, reddit submit pages, forum 'new topic' pages, github.com/*/issues/new), 0 otherwise. Willingness to ask publicly indicates safety.

indicators.name: team_communication_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to team communication tools: app.slack.com, discord.com/channels, teams.microsoft.com, zoom.us, meet.google.com, mail.google.com, outlook.com, notion.so, confluence. Collaboration platform visits.

indicators.name: community_discussion_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to developer community discussions: reddit.com/r/programming, reddit.com/r/haskell, reddit.com/r/learnprogramming, news.ycombinator.com comment pages, dev.to discussions, discord tech servers, IRC channels.

indicators.name: tech_news_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to tech news/community sites: news.ycombinator.com, techcrunch.com, arstechnica.com, theverge.com/tech, wired.com, dev.to articles, engineering blogs, programming podcasts, lobste.rs.

indicators.name: engineering_career_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches about engineering identity/career: 'software engineering career', 'being a developer', 'tech career path', 'engineering manager', 'staff engineer', 'principal engineer', 'tech lead', Paul Graham, engineering culture.

indicators.name: technology_comparison_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count 'X vs Y' technology comparisons: 'haskell vs scala', 'postgres vs mysql', 'vim vs emacs', 'react vs angular', 'aws vs gcp', 'docker vs podman'. Direct comparison searches indicate evaluating choices.

indicators.name: tooling_exploration_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches exploring development tools by choice: IDE comparisons, editor plugins, shell customization ('zsh', 'dotfiles'), workflow tools, productivity apps for developers, terminal emulators, development environment setup.
